title: Some graphs are less clear than others...
displayTitle: Some graphs are less clear than others...
body: Not all graphs and charts are easy to interpret and should be used with care. We have highlighted a number of these in the following section.

title: Pareto chart
body:
Combines a bar chart showing frequency and relative frequency, with a line displaying cumulative frequency. A bit lit combining the function of a bar chart with the key function of a pie chart. 

Be careful however as the presence of a line makes it look more like a line chart and thus could imply a strict order or time series nature to the data.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: In what way does the visualisation here mislead the viewer?

_items.text: Doesn’t start from 0 on the scale (baseline failure)
The area of the triangles does not represent the values

title: 1. Establishing data types and features
body:
Not all data is the same and therefore needs to be treated differently depending on its type and features. 

In this section, we will describe what data types are, and how to work with dimensions in the data to best help us in our EDA analysis.

_graphic.attribution: Adapt eLearning [CC0]
Maths is fun
Adapt eLearning [CC0]

title: Box and whisker plot
body:
A Box and Whisker Plot (or Box Plot) is a convenient way of visually displaying the distribution of data distribution through its quartiles.

The box and whisker plot may seem primitive in comparison to a histogram, but they essentially give the same information from a simply five number summary of the data.Multiple box plots can also be easily lined up to compare different characteristics or groupings of data.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Area or stacked area chart?
body: Is the chart shown here an area or stacked area chart?

_graphic.attribution: WTF Visualizations [All rights reserved]

title: Area and stacked area charts
body: Area charts are line charts but with the area below the line filled in with a certain colour or texture. This colour or texture adds an indication of something with volume (we might imagine it as a mountain range). A stacked area chart can be difficult to read: Does the shading suggest that all series will descend to zero (mountain ranges behind each other) or are stacked on top of each other?

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Outliers and robustness
body:
Take the following list of numbers, where two numbers have been added to the list from previously.

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18, 21, 104

There is now one extreme value in the list (104). This value is commonly referred to as an outlier as it doesn't fit the 'pattern' of the rest of the numbers.

The table below shows the new set of averages and the change against the previous list.

 First listSecond listChange
Mean1021+11
Median1013+3
Mode13130

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: 3D charts and bubble charts
body: When using different shapes you have to be careful what is representing the value in the data. Does adding 3D bars to a bar chart now mean that the volume (rather than height) of the bar represents the value? The same is true when using circles/bubbles. Remember the area is πr2, so be careful not to just substitute the value for r or you will distort the data significantly.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Line chart
body:
Line charts are used to display quantitative values over a continuous interval or time period. A line chart is most frequently used to show trends and analyse how the data has changed over time.

The direction of the lines on the graph works as a nice metaphor for the data: an upward slope indicates where values have increased and a downward slope indicates where values have decreased. The line's journey across the graph can create patterns that reveal trends in a dataset.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Bar chart
body:
The classic bar chart uses either horizontal or vertical bars (column chart) to show discrete, numerical comparisons across categories. One axis of the chart shows the specific categories being compared and the other axis represents a discrete value scale.

A bar chart is the clearest visualisation to show differences between categories.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Box-and-whisker plot
body:
A box-and-whisker plot (or box-plot) is a way to visually show the location, spread and range of the data using the five-number summary, as shown.

The whiskers show the minimum and maximum values and therefore illustrate the range of the data.

The box is plotted between the lower and upper quartiles. The box shows the interquartile range (IQR) or middle 50% and is the most significant basic robust measure of scale.

The size of the IQR boxes also show the spread of the data, with a smaller box representing a smaller spread and vice-versa.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
Cmglee [CC-BY-SA]

title: Histogram
body:
Histograms provide a visual interpretation of numerical data by indicating the number of data points that lie within a range of values. These ranges are called classes or bins. The frequency of the data that falls in each class is depicted by the use of a bar. The higher that the bar is, the greater the frequency. 

The shape of the histogram indicates if the data is skewed, and how This helps establish the type of analysis that can and cannot be performed on the data. Histograms also give an estimate of where values are concentrated, what the extremes are and whether there are any gaps or unusual values.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]

title: Stream graph
body:
A stream graph is a stacked area graph but with a central axis. Stream graphs are ideal for displaying high-volume datasets, to identify trends and patterns over time across a wide range of categories. 

The downside to stream graphs is that they suffer from legibility issues, as they are often very cluttered with large datasets. The categories with smaller values are often drowned out to make way for categories with much larger values, making it impossible to see all the data. Also, it's impossible to read the exact values visualised in a stream graph, as there is no axis to use as a reference.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]
Max Van Kleek [CC-BY]

title: In what way does the visualisation here mislead the viewer?

_items.text: Areas of each slices do not represent the values

title: The distribution of data
body:
Another important aspect to consider is the measures of dispersion, also known as distributions. As with averages, not all distributions are equivalent and analysis techniques can vary depending on the spread of the data. 

Read more about each below:

_items.title: Normal distribution
_items.body:
A normal distribution (or bell curve) is a symmetrical distribution where the mean, median and mode are all the same.

Many things closely follow a normal distribution:

  • heights of people
  • errors in measurements
  • blood pressure
  • marks on a test

_items.title: Negatively (left) skewed
_items.body:
A negatively skewed distribution is influenced by outliers at the lower end of the data's range. This means that the mean would be a lower value than the median and mode. It seems counterintuitive that although the majority of the data is on the higher side, its statistical term is 'negatively-skewed'. 

Examples of negatively skewed data include:

  • retirement age
  • book prices
  • age of death (in developed countries)

_items.title: Positively (right) skewed
_items.body:
A positively skewed distribution is influenced by outliers at the higher end of the data's range. In this case, the mean is greater than the mode or median.

Examples of positively skewed data include:

  • capital project costs
  • household income
  • property prices

_items.title: Non-normal (jumbled up) data
_items.body:
Data with a non-normal distribution can occur. 

There are still pieces of analysis that can be performed on the data, but these are different from the distributions covered in this module.

Examples include:

  • Cost of healthcare
  • Crime rate data

title: 2. Descriptive methods to analyse data
body: Descriptive statistics uses measures of central tendency and dispersion (spread) to summarise the features of a collection of information in a given data set. These measures can be either a representation of the entire population or a sample of a population. And their aim is to provide a summary of the content, rather to infer something about the population at large, in which case one will rely on inferential statistics, and apply probability theory and nonparametric statistics.

title: Standard deviations
body:
The standard deviation (SD) is a measure of how spread out numbers are.

When we calculate the standard deviation we find that generally:

  • 68% of values are within 1 standard deviation of the mean
  • 95% of values are within 2 standard deviations of the mean
  • 99.7% of values are within 3 standard deviations of the mean

The standard deviation can be used in data that has a normal distribution – to determine the proportion of values that lie within particular ranges of the mean. Or to think of it another way, if the mean is a good measure of the average, then standard deviation is a good measure of variance.  

Standard deviation can be used to also be used to identify outliers (points outside of 2 standard deviations), test statistical significance or even with machine learning and data models to sanity check predictions.

title: Summary
body:
Exploratory data analysis (EDA) is an approach used to understand and analyse the main characteristics of a dataset. EDA will often use a combination of descriptive and graphical methods in order to:

  • identify issues in the data
  • test assumptions and suggest hypothesis for evaluation
  • support the selection of appropriate analytical tools and techniques
  • provide a basis for the further collection or pre-processing of data prior to evaluation.

There are a wide variety of techniques that can be used to perform EDA, each suited for different types of data and objectives. Pick carefully when doing your own EDA; even picking the wrong measure of average can lead to problems!

title: Which measure of central tendency is most robust?
body: Which measure of central tendency is most robust to outliers?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

The mean is badly affected by outliers, just one large number and the mean can be larger than the second highest number in the list. The mean is the least robust.

In this example the mode is the most robust, however it is not the most robust measure of central tendency. Adding a number of the same values can have a profound affect on the mode. 

The median is the most robust measure of central tendency in the situations where outliers are included. In situations when we have to address the outliers, a trim can be performed. In this case removing the highest and lowest values would realign the mean and median.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The mean is badly affected by outliers, just one large number and the mean can be larger than the second highest number in the list. The mean is the least robust.

In this example the mode is the most robust, however it is not the most robust measure of central tendency. Adding a number of the same values can have a profound affect on the mode. 

The median is the most robust measure of central tendency in the situations where outliers are included. In situations when we have to address the outliers, a trim can be performed. In this case removing the highest and lowest values would realign the mean and median.

title: 3. Graphical methods to analyse data
body: Graphical analysis can identify patterns and trends. There are many different types of graphs and charts suited for different types of graphical analysis. We have summarised the key points about each in the section below.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
Max Van Kleek [CC-BY]

title: Measures of Central Tendency
body:
Measures of central tendency, also called averages, identify the central position within a set of data, which can be measured in three possible ways: mean, median, and mode.

Expand the sections below to discover more:

_items.title: mean
_items.body:
The most common type of average is the arithmetic mean also denoted as with the symbol μ. And it can be used for both, discrete and continuous data.

It is calculated by adding up all the numbers in a list and dividing by the number of items in the list.

For example take the following list of numbers:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

The sum of the number is 70, there are 7 items in the list. Therefore the mean is 10 (70 / 7).

 

The mean is usually the best measurement for central tendency when the distribution of the data is continuous and symmetrical; also known as having a normal distribution.

_items.title: median
_items.body:
The median is the middle number of the list where the numbers are ranked in order.  And you can also think of the median as the mean of two data points spanning the middle for an even number of data points. 

For example take the following list of numbers that are already ranked in ascending order:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

There are seven numbers, the middle number will be the fourth one in the list. Therefore the median of this list of numbers is 10. 

 

The median is usually the best measurement for central tendency when the data is skewed or when dealing with ordinal data.

_items.title: mode
_items.body:
The mode is the most frequently occurring number in the list. 

Taking our list of numbers:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

The most frequently occurring number is 13.

 

The mode is usually the best measurement for central tendency when dealing with nominal data.

title: Pie Chart
body: A pie chart shows things as a proportion of the whole. They are best used with percentage scales. Pie charts are ideal for giving the reader a quick idea of the proportional distribution of the data. They are not great when there are a large number of categories or the differences between segments are not significant. They can also be misleading if proportional representation is not necessary for a particular analysis.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
body:
The analysis that we conduct in the exploratory phase is defined by the scope of the project. But exploratory data analysis is part of every stage in the project lifecycle where data is involved as exploring the information it holds help us shape our decisions.

This module will give you the practical skills you need to understand how to best conduct an EDA by focussing on three main aspects: 

  1. Establishing the type and features of data
  2. Descriptive methods to analyse data
  3. Graphical methods to analyse data

title: Measures of central tendency?
body: Can you work out the following from our dataset? Please note the answer must be given in exactly the format shown on the left (e.g. "5m22s").

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The median and mode are both the same in this dataset at 6m00s. The mean is the most challenging to work out as you need to convert everything into seconds and visa-versa to work it out using a calculator. In this case the mean in 6m33s.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The median and mode are both the same in this dataset at 6m00s. The mean is the most challenging to work out as you need to convert everything into seconds and visa-versa to work it out using a calculator. In this case the mean in 6m33s.

title: Scatter-plot
body: Scatterplots are used to establish the relationship (or lack of) between two variables. Various types of correlation can be interpreted through the patterns displayed on scatterplots. They are often used in linear regression where a positive (or negative) straight line of best fit is identified.  They can also be used to identify non-linear correlations or clusters (no correlation) in the data. Scatterplots can also be plotted in more than two dimensions but these can be difficult to read.

_graphic.attribution: Data Viz Catalogue [All rights reserved]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Even though it might look positively skewed, it is actually normally distributed by the data shown. Here the mean, median and mode are all in the same category (0-10 minutes late). Very few planes land late compared to the amount that fly!

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Even though it might look positively skewed, it is actually normally distributed by the data shown. Here the mean, median and mode are all in the same category (0-10 minutes late). Very few planes land late compared to the amount that fly!

title: Choosing the right graph
body: Match the following example to the most appropriate graphical method of exploration.

_items.text: Number of busses on the road at different times of day
Number of planes late arriving, grouped into 30 minute intervals
An overall split on project spend in different categories

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

If you have data over time, then a line chart is best for the first question. Grouping this requires a histogram in the second question. Comparing two variables to find a correlation is best done with a scatter plot while a breakdown on project spending is nicely visualised in a pie chart.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If you have data over time, then a line chart is best for the first question. Grouping this requires a histogram in the second question. Comparing two variables to find a correlation is best done with a scatter plot while a breakdown on project spending is nicely visualised in a pie chart.

title: Data types
body: Broadly speaking there are two main types of data that can be used in EDA:

_items.title: Categorical Data
_items.body:
In categorical, values are constrained within a certain range. An example, is discrete data. 

There are two main types of categorical data:

  • Nominal data: Such as gender or language. These labels (or values) are limited in range but there is no intrinsic order to the values. 
  • Ordinal data: Very similar to nominal data, but where order matters, e.g. customer satisfaction, education level.

_graphic.attribution: Niklas Donges [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Numerical data
_items.body:
Numerical data can be discrete continuous, or be a ratio. 

  • Discrete data represent items that can be counted or listed. For example, the number of heads in 100 coin flips takes on values from 0 through 100.
  • Continuous data represent measurements and can only be described using intervals. For example, the exact amount of gas purchased at the pump for cars with 20-gallon tanks would be continuous data from 0 gallons to 20 gallons, represented by the interval [0, 20], inclusive. You might pump 8.40 gallons, or 8.41, or 8.414863 gallons, or any possible number from 0 to 20. In this way, continuous data can be thought of as being uncountably infinite.
  • Ratio data are numbers that can be compared as multiples of one another, and can be multiplied and divided. For example, not only is the difference between 1 and 2 the same as between 3 and 4, but also that 4 is twice as much as 2.

_graphic.attribution: Niklas Donges [All rights reserved]

title: Dimensionality
body:
The majority of data we deal with today contains a high number of dimensions, also known as multivariate. This is simply a way of saying that each record in a dataset has a high number of variables

  • One variable = univariate
  • Two variables = bivariate
  • More than three variables = multivariate

When a high number of variables are collected we must be aware of variable dependence: when a change of value for one variable affects the value of another, thus the variables are intrinsically connected (e.g air pressure and temperature).

Highly dimensional datasets could also be semi-structured or contain nested data, thus increasing the complexity.

title: Sampling
body:
When gathering or re-using data it is of critical importance to understand how data has been sampled. It is very rare that a dataset will be complete and represent the whole population, thus at some point a sample will have been, or will need to be taken. 

To ensure a sample is fair, we have to pay careful attention to how we select our sample because it is important for it to be an actual representation of the population and not contain data that favours one particular characteristic.

title: Which sampling technique would you choose?
body: If you were tasked with sampling the employees of ARUP for use in data analysis, which sampling technique would be most suitable?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

ARUP has many offices that all part of the population we want to represented. The best approach to sampling in this case would be a clustered sampling technique containing data from all offices. Within this clustered approach a systematic sample would be best to ensure data is collected about all different roles within the company.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

ARUP has many offices that all part of the population we want to represented. The best approach to sampling in this case would be a clustered sampling technique containing data from all offices. Within this clustered approach a systematic sample would be best to ensure data is collected about all different roles within the company.

_graphic.attribution: Adapt eLearning [CC0]

title: Fair sampling?
body: If we want to conduct an analysis of the employees at ARUP, will a sample from one office be an appropriate representation of the whole population (all employees)?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The employees in one office are very likely differ from those in other Arup offices, thus sampling from one office will likely lead to bias in the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The employees in one office are very likely differ from those in other Arup offices, thus sampling from one office will likely lead to bias in the data.

title: Test your knowledge
body: See if you can chose the right graphical ways to evaluate data and identify the problems and deceptions in some others.

title: Flight delays
body:
The following data represents the arrival delay of planes at an airport taken over a 2 month period. 

10-20 minutes early4,404 flights
0-10 minutes early22,722 flights
0-10 minutes late20,040 flights
10-20 minutes late8,106 flights
20-30 minutes late3,433 flights
30-40 minutes late2,757 flights
40-50 minutes late1,849 flights

 

Which of the following plots represents the spread of the flight delay data?

title: Emergency service performance
body:
The following is a set of response times of emergency services to incidents:

4m11s6m00s
4m30s6m20s
5m32s6m50s
5m48s7m30s
5m59s13m23s
6m00s

title: What data type?
body: See if you can match the following dataset descriptions to the most appropriate data types.
instruction: Select your answers and then click 'submit'

_items.text: Arrival airport code of a flight
Arrival delay of flights to an airport (in minutes)

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

If there is a limited range of options, no matter how many options then the data type is categorical as is the case the airport codes. With regards to the delay, this is a continuous numeric. It is not a ratio as there is not a zero value due to fact the flight could arrive early.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If there is a limited range of options, no matter how many options then the data type is categorical as is the case the airport codes. With regards to the delay, this is a continuous numeric. It is not a ratio as there is not a zero value due to fact the flight could arrive early.

_graphic.attribution: Adapt eLearning [CC0]

title: Why Exploratory Data Analysis?
body:
The outputs of the exploratory analysis can shape the outputs of the discovery phase and influence the project motivation, and it can also inform the design of the solution that will be building. 

We can explore data from one source, and we can compare it to the information we analyse from multiple sources. The analysis of the combined information is how we can best ensure we make the most informed decisions. Hence, the Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is an approach that uses a combination of descriptive and graphical methods to:

  • Identify issues in the data
  • Determine relationships and general trends in the data
  • Test assumptions and suggest hypotheses for evaluation
  • Support the selection of appropriate analytical tools and techniques
  • Provide a basis for the further collection or data pre-processing prior to evaluation.

_graphic.attribution: Adapt eLearning [CC0]
Adapt eLearning [CC0]

title: Data types
body:
It is important to have a good understanding of the different data types - also called measurement scales - because this conditions which statistical measurement can be used for a given data type.

Imagine you are evaluating the reasons for delays in transport systems. You will need data on delay duration and reason. However when you look at the delay data you might find the delay duration hasn’t been collected. In its place  a boolean true or false is present if there was a delay. The data type doesn’t match expectation and thus limits further analysis.

title: Importance of descriptive statistics
body: Why is establishing the spread and central tendency of data important in projects at ARUP?

_items.text: To check the data is as expected and doesn’t contain bias
To identify and dispose of outliers
To inform the choice of sampling technique

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Before any conclusions can be drawn from data it is important to check that the data is in the expected shape and doesn’t contain bias. In the majority of cases, the shape of data will be known by domain experts. Take for example a dataset of salaries in a company. This should always be positively skewed (mean higher than the median); if it is normally distributed then something is a miss.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Before any conclusions can be drawn from data it is important to check that the data is in the expected shape and doesn’t contain bias. In the majority of cases, the shape of data will be known by domain experts. Take for example a dataset of salaries in a company. This should always be positively skewed (mean higher than the median); if it is normally distributed then something is a miss.

_items.title: Whole population
_items.body:
A population is a whole, it's every member of a group. A population is the opposite of a sample. 
It is very rare that the complete population will be available (or collectable).  

Additionally, using the whole population to build a model or some inferential statistic should be avoided as there is no way to evaluate the model against any other samples; as no other samples can be taken.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Random sampling
_items.body:
In a random sample, each individual data point is chosen entirely by chance and each member of the population has an equal chance of being selected. 

Random samples require a way of naming or numbering the target population and then using some type of raffle method to choose those to make up the sample.

Random sampling is the best method of selecting your sample from the population of interest as there is less chance of sampling bias.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Convenience sampling
_items.body:
Convenience sampling is perhaps the easiest method of sampling.

Convenience sampling is a non-probabilistic method of sampling where the sample is essentially the most willing subset of the population. 

In an ordered list, this might simply be the first X items. Or if collecting data from people it will be those available and willing to take part.

Useful results can be obtained, but the results are prone to significant volunteer bias.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Clustered sampling
_items.body:
In a clustered sample, the population is divided into subgroups, known as clusters, which are randomly selected to be included in the study. 

Clusters are usually already defined, e.g. Arup offices. 

In single-stage cluster sampling, all members of the chosen clusters are then included in the study. In two-stage cluster sampling, a selection of individuals from each cluster is then randomly selected for inclusion.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Systematic clustering
_items.body:
In systematic sampling, individuals are selected at regular intervals from the population. 

Systematic sampling is often more convenient than random sampling, and it is easy to administer. However, it may also lead to bias, for example if there are underlying patterns in the order of the individuals in the population.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Stratified sampling
_items.body:
In stratified sampling, the population is first divided into subgroups (or strata) who all share a similar characteristic. 
The sample is then obtained by either taking equal sample sizes from each subgroup or taking a proportional sample (as shown).

Stratified sampling improves the accuracy and representativeness of the results by reducing sampling bias. However, it requires knowledge of the appropriate characteristics of the population (the details of which are not always available), and it can be difficult to decide which characteristic(s) to stratify by.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
